title: How to Post Sensitive Content on Your Instagram Story or Profile

steps.title: Open Instagram and tap the profile icon.
steps.content: Open Instagram and tap the profile icon. One way to allow followers to choose whether they want to see something or not is to create a slideshow-type post , with the first image(s) in the post displaying the spoiler or warning image you create. Then, viewers can decide whether they want to swipe left to see the sensitive content. You can also post your sensitive content warning image on your story to warn people that upcoming images or videos might be upsetting. Keep in mind that even if you're sharing content behind a warning, you'll still need to abide by Instagram's community guidelines .

steps.title: Tap the + at the bottom.
steps.content: Tap the + at the bottom. The easiest way to create a sensitive content warning is to create an image with the Instagram Story editor. Then, you can use that image on posts and stories.

steps.title: Tap STORY on the bottom menu.
steps.content: Tap STORY on the bottom menu. This opens the Story editor.

steps.title: Tap Create.
steps.content: Tap Create . It's on the left panel. This opens Create mode, where you can start editing your sensitive content warning or spoiler.

steps.title: Enter your text.
steps.content: Enter your text. Tap Aa at the top of the screen to enter typing mode, then type the text you want on your warning. For example, you could create an image that says "Sensitive Content Warning—swipe left to see it," "Spoiler Alert Ahead," or "Trigger Warning," followed by a clean/safe description of the content you're sharing. It can be helpful to explain why the content might be upsetting. For example, "The following content might be triggering for trauma survivors." [1] X Research source You'll see some text formatting options at the top below what you’ve typed. You can tap the colorful circle to choose a different text color, try a different font, or choose any text effects. To increase the text size, drag the left slider up. To decrease it, drag the slider down.

steps.title: Tap Done when you're finished typing.
steps.content: Tap Done when you're finished typing. This saves your text and displays a preview.

steps.title: Edit your sensitive content warning.
steps.content: Edit your sensitive content warning. For example, you might want to change the size of the text even further by placing two fingers over the text and pushing outward (to increase it) or inward (to make it smaller). You can also tap the circle at the top to change the background color. You can tap the sticker icon at the top to insert GIFs and other features, but avoid adding music—you'll need to save the warning image to your phone or tablet, and Instagram won't let you do that if a song is included. Using bright colors can make your warning stand out more on the feed.

steps.title: Tap the Save button to save your image to your phone or tablet.
steps.content: Tap the Save button to save your image to your phone or tablet. Depending on your device, you might see Save or an arrow pointing downward at the top-right corner. If you don't see one of these options, tap the three horizontal dots at the upper-right corner first. Once your image is saved, you can tap the X at the top-left to close the editor, and then tap X at the top-right to return to your feed. Now that you have a sensitive content warning image, learn how to use it to post sensitive content on your feed and on your Story . You can make multiple images that say different things and download them all to your phone. You can share up to 10 photos and videos in a single gallery post (some users may have the option to add more than that), so add as many warning images as you need—this gives people time to really make the conscious decision to see your sensitive content. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Create a new Instagram post.
steps.content: Create a new Instagram post. Now that you have a warning image, you can create a gallery post . Start by opening the Instagram app and tapping the + at the bottom of the screen. [3] X Research source The POST option at the bottom should be selected by default. If it's not, tap POST at the bottom now.

steps.title: Tap the two overlapping squares below the preview image.
steps.content: Tap the two overlapping squares below the preview image. On some devices, you'll see Select Multiple . This allows you to create a carousel of photos and/or videos, which you can preface with your sensitive content warning image. After tapping this option, small circles will appear at the top corners of each photo in your gallery.

steps.title: Select your sensitive content warning as the first image.
steps.content: Select your sensitive content warning as the first image. This will place a "1" in the upper-right corner of the thumbnail image—this means your content warning will be the first item in your carousel post.

steps.title: Tap the other images and/or videos you want to share in order.
steps.content: Tap the other images and/or videos you want to share in order. After adding the warning images, add the sensitive content you want to share. As you tap images and/or videos, a number will appear at each image's corner. This number shows the order in which they'll be shown.

steps.title: Tap Next.
steps.content: Tap Next . It's at the bottom-right or top-right corner, depending on your device.

steps.title: Add filters/edits and tap Done.
steps.content: Add filters/edits and tap Done . If you want, you can select some background music from the bottom, or use the options at the top to select filters, add text, and more.

steps.title: Enter a caption.
steps.content: Enter a caption. The caption is another great place to add a warning about the sensitive content you're sharing. You can type some thoughts about why sharing this sensitive content is important to you and why people should (or shouldn't) swipe left to view it. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Share to share your post.
steps.content: Tap Share to share your post. Once your post is live, you'll see your sensitive content warning or spoiler alert in action. Swiping left across the first image will proceed to the next one, and so on. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Create a new Instagram Story.
steps.content: Create a new Instagram Story. Once you've created your sensitive content warning image, you can add it to your Instagram story before uploading the sensitive, NSFW, or other potentially triggering content. Tap + at the bottom of Instagram, then select STORY to get started.

steps.title: Select an image from your iPhone or Android's camera roll/gallery.
steps.content: Select an image from your iPhone or Android's camera roll/gallery. Tap the square at the bottom-left to browse the photos and videos on your phone or tablet, then tap the sensitive content warning you created.

steps.title: Tap Your story to add it to your story.
steps.content: Tap Your story to add it to your story. Alternatively, you can first add other elements to your spoiler warning image, such as music, filters, more text , and stickers.

steps.title: Upload the sensitive or NSFW content to your Story.
steps.content: Upload the sensitive or NSFW content to your Story. Now that your content warning is in your story, you can post sensitive or triggering content without worrying about catching someone off guard.

steps.title: Use a content warning GIF on stories and reels.
steps.content: Use a content warning GIF on stories and reels. When you create a story or a reel , you can search through thousands of fun GIFs to add to your creation. Just tap the sticker icon, then type content warning into the search box to see lots of options.

steps.title: Record a content warning video.
steps.content: Record a content warning video. Before sharing sensitive content in a story, use the story camera to record yourself giving a verbal content warning. Add some accompanying "Content Warning" text to the video before sharing, just in case anyone is scrolling through stories while muted.

steps.title: Use the captions.
steps.content: Use the captions. This is not recommended, but you could just type something like "this post contains sensitive content" into your post's caption. However, it's likely that nobody will see it until they've already seen the photo or video, so you should only do this if you've already shared a post that could be considered sensitive and have a good reason not to take down the post and start over.
